artist: Koo Kyung Sook; Published by Koo Kyung Sook
description: abstract image; black on white; portrait-like silhouette with head and shoulders but without facial features or clothing--organic twining plant-like forms with twisted thorny branches on face
marks: Signature, Title, Date and Edition bottom edge on back, in pencil: [3/3  MARKINGS 14-
medium: Photo-derived woodcut printed on thin Korean mulberry paper, laminated to five further layers of the same paper
provenance: The artist, Sacramento, Calif.; (Charles Young Fine Prints and Drawings, Portland, Conn.); sold to MIA, 2015.
text: Koo Kyung Sook’s monochromatic woodcut is a dense, gestural mélange of line and form that introduces a decided ambiguity to this unconventional self-portrait. Here, abstraction pushes representation to the edge of incomprehensibility. The features of Koo’s face and body are nearly obscured by a fluid thicket of layered marks of different size, shape, and value, leaving the viewer to decipher her transient physiognomy. This sense of a hidden identity is intentional, a reference to women’s “invisible” status in male-dominated societies, such as Koo’s native Korea.
title: Markings 14-I
